name: demand
description: Demand is the willingness and ability of the people within a market area to purchase a good or service. Economists generally assume there is an inverse relationship between the price of a good and the quantity demanded by buyers.

clips.name: The Couch
clips.description: When George joins a book club to impress a girl and then finds the reading too costly, his demand for a substitute good (the video of the novel) rises to ridiculous proportions. In the end, he finds that the movie and the book are imperfect substitutes.

tags.name: demand
tags.description: Demand is the willingness and ability of the people within a market area to purchase a good or service. Economists generally assume there is an inverse relationship between the price of a good and the quantity demanded by buyers.

tags.name: substitutes
tags.description: Two goods are substitutes if, when the market price of the first good rises, the demand for the second good also rises.

source.title: Seinfeld
source.description: Seinfeld ran for nine seasons on NBC and became famous as a “show about nothing.” Basically, the show allows viewers to follow the antics of Jerry, George, Elaine, and Kramer as they move through their daily lives, often encountering interesting people or dealing with special circumstances. It is the simplicity of Seinfeld that makes it so appropriate for use in economics courses. Using these clips (as well as clips from other television shows or movies) makes economic concepts come alive, making them more real for students. Ultimately, students will start seeing economics everywhere – in other TV shows, in popular music, and most importantly, in their own lives.

clips.name: The Glasses
clips.description: Jerry is getting a new air conditioning unit.  Elaine asks why, because he's never wanted air conditioning before.  But Jerry's new girlfriend feels more comfortable in with air conditioning, so Jerry is getting one—his demand has increased.

clips.name: The Non-Fat Yogurt
clips.description: Kramer has invested in a fat-free yogurt shop, but Jerry and Elaine begin to gain weight after indulging in it.

tags.name: demand
tags.description: Demand is the willingness and ability of the people within a market area to purchase a good or service. Economists generally assume there is an inverse relationship between the price of a good and the quantity demanded by buyers.

tags.name: value of information
tags.description: The value of information is the amount a decision maker would be willing to pay for information prior to making a decision.

source.title: Seinfeld

clips.name: The Old Man
clips.description: Kramer and Newman try to sell used records to a dealer who is buying them.  He offers what they believe to be an insulting offer.  This shows that value is determined by both scarcity and desire;  without demand, even a rare commodity has no value.

clips.name: The Postponement
clips.description: Elaine is consulting a rabbi, who offers her Snackwell's Cookies.  He says he fears that knowing they're fat free may cause people to overindulge.  Making them fat-free lowers the price of eating them; consumers respond by eating more.

tags.name: demand
tags.description: Demand is the willingness and ability of the people within a market area to purchase a good or service. Economists generally assume there is an inverse relationship between the price of a good and the quantity demanded by buyers.

tags.name: law of demand
tags.description: The law of demand suggests that there is an inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded.  Thus, as price falls, individuals consume more and vice versa.
